Gene Usage

December 10 2022

Source: vignettes/gene-usage.Rmd
gene-usage.Rmd


This vignette provides detailed examples for calculating and visualizing V(D)J gene usage. For the examples shown below, we use data for splenocytes from BL6 and MD4 mice collected using the 10X Genomics scRNA-seq platform. MD4 B cells are monoclonal and specifically bind hen egg lysozyme.

library(djvdj)
library(Seurat)
library(ggplot2)
library(RColorBrewer)

# Add V(D)J data to object
vdj_dirs <- c(
  BL6 = system.file("extdata/splen/BL6_BCR", package = "djvdj"),
  MD4 = system.file("extdata/splen/MD4_BCR", package = "djvdj")
)

so <- splen_so |>
  import_vdj(vdj_dirs, define_clonotypes = "cdr3_gene")


Calculating gene usage

The calc_gene_usage() function will calculate the number of cells (â€˜freqâ€™) and percentage of cells (â€˜pctâ€™) with each gene in the data_cols column(s). The â€˜n_cellsâ€™ column shows the total number of cells used for calculating percentages. A data.frame is returned summarizing the results.

so |>
  calc_gene_usage(data_cols = "v_gene")
#> # A tibble: 103 Ã— 4
#>    v_gene     n_cells  freq   pct
#>    <chr>        <int> <int> <dbl>
#>  1 IGKV5-43       329   156 47.4 
#>  2 IGKV10-96      329    14  4.26
#>  3 IGKV6-17       329     9  2.74
#>  4 IGLV1          329     9  2.74
#>  5 IGKV14-111     329     8  2.43
#>  6 IGKV1-117      329     7  2.13
#>  7 IGKV13-84      329     7  2.13
#>  8 IGKV1-135      329     6  1.82
#>  9 IGKV19-93      329     6  1.82
#> 10 IGKV3-4        329     6  1.82
#> # â€¦ with 93 more rows

To perform gene usage calculations separately for cell clusters (or samples), provide the meta.data column containing cluster labels to the cluster_col argument. Here we see that the MD4 samples almost exclusively use a single V segment (IGKV5-43), which is expected since MD4 B cells are monoclonal.

so |>
  calc_gene_usage(
    data_cols = "v_gene",
    cluster_col = "sample"
  )
#> # A tibble: 618 Ã— 5
#>    v_gene     sample n_cells  freq    pct
#>    <chr>      <chr>    <dbl> <int>  <dbl>
#>  1 IGKV5-43   MD4-2       55    55 100   
#>  2 IGKV5-43   MD4-3       54    51  94.4 
#>  3 IGKV5-43   MD4-1       50    47  94   
#>  4 IGKV10-96  BL6-1       55     6  10.9 
#>  5 IGKV10-96  BL6-3       52     5   9.62
#>  6 IGKV14-111 BL6-2       63     6   9.52
#>  7 IGLV1      BL6-3       52     4   7.69
#>  8 IGHV6-6    BL6-1       55     4   7.27
#>  9 IGKV6-17   BL6-2       63     4   6.35
#> 10 IGKV8-24   BL6-2       63     4   6.35
#> # â€¦ with 608 more rows

To only perform calculations for a specific chain, use the chain argument. In this example we are only returning results for the IGK chain. Here we see some values in the â€˜v_geneâ€™ column labeled as â€˜Noneâ€™, this shows the number of cells that did not have a V gene segment identified.

so |>
  calc_gene_usage(
    data_cols   = "v_gene",
    cluster_col = "sample",
    chain       = "IGK"
  )
#> # A tibble: 336 Ã— 5
#>    v_gene     sample n_cells  freq    pct
#>    <chr>      <chr>    <dbl> <int>  <dbl>
#>  1 IGKV5-43   MD4-2       55    55 100   
#>  2 IGKV5-43   MD4-3       54    51  94.4 
#>  3 IGKV5-43   MD4-1       50    47  94   
#>  4 IGKV10-96  BL6-1       55     6  10.9 
#>  5 IGKV10-96  BL6-3       52     5   9.62
#>  6 None       BL6-3       52     5   9.62
#>  7 IGKV14-111 BL6-2       63     6   9.52
#>  8 IGKV6-17   BL6-2       63     4   6.35
#>  9 IGKV8-24   BL6-2       63     4   6.35
#> 10 IGKV3-4    BL6-3       52     3   5.77
#> # â€¦ with 326 more rows

If two columns are provided to the data_cols argument, the number of cells containing each combination of genes is returned.

so |>
  calc_gene_usage(
    data_cols = c("v_gene", "j_gene"),
    cluster_col = "sample"
  )
#> # A tibble: 1,062 Ã— 6
#>    v_gene     j_gene sample n_cells  freq    pct
#>    <chr>      <chr>  <chr>    <dbl> <int>  <dbl>
#>  1 IGKV5-43   IGKJ2  MD4-2       55    55 100   
#>  2 IGKV5-43   IGKJ2  MD4-3       54    51  94.4 
#>  3 IGKV5-43   IGKJ2  MD4-1       50    47  94   
#>  4 IGKV14-111 IGKJ2  BL6-2       63     4   6.35
#>  5 IGKV10-96  IGKJ1  BL6-3       52     3   5.77
#>  6 IGLV1      IGLJ1  BL6-3       52     3   5.77
#>  7 IGKV10-96  IGKJ2  BL6-1       55     3   5.45
#>  8 IGKV10-96  IGKJ1  BL6-2       63     3   4.76
#>  9 IGKV1-135  IGKJ1  BL6-3       52     2   3.85
#> 10 IGKV10-96  IGKJ2  BL6-3       52     2   3.85
#> # â€¦ with 1,052 more rows


Plotting gene usage

The plot_gene_usage() function will summarize the frequency of each gene segment. By default if a single column is passed to the data_cols argument, a bargraph will be returned. The number of top genes to include in the plot can be specified with the n_genes argument. Alternatively, a vector of gene names can be passed to the vdj_genes argument to plot a set of desired genes.

so |>
  plot_gene_usage(
    data_cols   = "v_gene",
    cluster_col = "orig.ident",
    n_genes     = 20
  )

By default, percentages are shown on the y-axis, to instead plot the frequency, set the units argument to â€˜frequencyâ€™.

so |>
  plot_gene_usage(
    data_cols   = "v_gene",
    cluster_col = "orig.ident",
    units       = "frequency"
  )

If two columns are passed to the data_cols argument, a heatmap will be generated summarizing the usage of segment pairs. If a column is provided to the cluster_col argument, a separate heatmap will be generated for each cluster.

so |>
  plot_gene_usage(
    data_cols   = c("v_gene", "j_gene"),
    cluster_col = "orig.ident",
    n_genes     = 15
  )

Plot colors can be adjusted using the plot_colors argument. In addition, plot_gene_usage() returns a ggplot object that can be modified with ggplot2 functions such as ggplot2::theme(). Plots can be further adjusted by passing aesthetic parameters directly to ggplot2, e.g.Â alpha, linetype, color, etc.

so |>
  plot_gene_usage(
    data_cols   = "v_gene",
    cluster_col = "orig.ident",
    plot_colors = c(BL6 = "#3288BD", MD4 = "#D53E4F"),
    
    color = "black",  # parameters to pass to ggplot2
    alpha = 0.7
  ) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90))


Circos plot

A circos plot can be created by setting the method argument to â€˜circosâ€™. This plot will summarize the number of cells containing the different segment pairs. The number of cells is shown as the axis labels for each sample.

In this example, we are summarizing the segment usage for the entire dataset (BL6 and MD4 cells combined). The cluster_col argument can be used to create a separate plot for each sample. Labels can be rotated to eliminate overlapping text using the rotate_labels argument.

so |>
  plot_gene_usage(
    data_cols     = c("v_gene", "j_gene"),
    method        = "circos",
    n_genes       = 6,
    rotate_labels = TRUE
  )

Plot colors can be modified using the plot_colors argument, additional parameters can be passed directly to circlize::chordDiagram(). In this example we add a border around the links and scale the plot so each sample is the same width.

so |>
  plot_gene_usage(
    data_cols   = c("v_gene", "j_gene"),
    method      = "circos",
    n_genes     = 8,
    plot_colors = brewer.pal(10, "Spectral"),
    
    link.border = "black",  # parameters to pass to chordDiagram()
    scale       = TRUE
  )

Gene segment usage can be plotted separately for cell clusters (or samples) using the cluster_col argument. The number of rows used to arrange plots can be modified using the panel_nrow argument.

so |>
  plot_gene_usage(
    data_cols   = c("v_gene", "j_gene"),
    method      = "circos",
    cluster_col = "sample",
    n_genes     = 5,
    panel_nrow  = 2,
    scale       = TRUE
  )
